data.text: Anyone Tried Tronsmart Space S1 Open Ear Earphones when Cycling?

Hi All, I have an Aftershokz Aeropex bone conducting headphone which I don't leave for a bike ride without (whatever distance). They are great and unobtrusive as they don't cover the ears. I came across this device today, which promises not to obstruct the ears as well, but are not bone conducting. Does anyone have any experience with them or similar from other brands? (I have Tronsmart bluetooth speakers and they are good). Price is low enough to give it a try, even if I get no answers here. PS. Comments such as "you shouldn't listen to music while you ride", etc, are unnecessary. If you don't have any experience about this device or similar ones, no comment is necessary ðŸ˜‰.

data.text: Bizarre. Just did a short read
data.author: Dan Manning

data.text: bone conducting headphones work really well!
data.author: Tom Adagio Sisk

data.text: seems like they would rattle fillings. But Iâ€™ve never tried them. I use a little s1 speaker that hangs from my handle bars. Itâ€™s way too hot and humid in Missouri to cover or put anything around your ears. My ears used to fill with sweat and they would come out all the time when Iâ€™d try to wear ear buds. Other bonus is I donâ€™t have to call out my passes as much in public parks. Iâ€™m loud enough to where people know Iâ€™m coming.
data.author: Dan Manning

data.text: yeah, I use a buckshot speaker as well, but I've tried the bone conducting headset and it is super clear, and wouldn't aggravate all those other folks on the trail who, oddly enough, don't want to hear my Trombone Shorty spotify playlist!
data.author: Tom Adagio Sisk

data.text: its kind of something you need to experience to understand. If you are someone who perpetually listens to something on your phone, then these are great because they let you keep situational awareness.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: They are now called Shokz and I have the Open Run. Just brilliant for practicality and keeping my dopamine demanding, adhd brain stimulated. Way better than what comes to mind when I read "made in China."
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: My Aeropex says "Made in China" on the warranty card and it is a genuine one. It's not the origin that defines quality... its materials, handcraft, processes and procedures.
data.author: Paulo Seth

data.text: Precisely my point. It is really, really well made and if someone thinks that made in China means it will break tomorrow, not this time.
data.author: Adam Craig

data.text: apologies... misread your comment.
data.author: Paulo Seth

data.text: If you have a camera, phone, computer, almost anything electronic these days, it is often made/assembled in China. This includes the top Japanese brands.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: Yeah I am old enough to remember when the same thing was said about Japan, Taiwan, Korea and even Hong Kong, that is now said about China. Started with small transistor electronics, then household appliances, then automobiles, and then heavy machinery, now those countries are leaders in all those fields. Now you wouldn't by something manufactured in the west for fear the company will go out of business the week after you buy it and void the warranty.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: My experience with cheap headsets is that the frequency response is limited. I have no expericence with these headsets, but they are not bone conducting and so the sound will be mostly travelling through air, unlike buds which fit directly into the ear canal (which acts like a bass bin). The IPX5 rating is not too encouraging, I would want IPX6 if I was going to ride and use these in the rain. Like you say, cheap enough to give them a go, but I have tried cheap bone conducting phones and they are ok. If you do opt to try them, let us know how they perform.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I'd be seriously surprised if they were better than the Aftershokz, why are you considering something else?
data.author: Paul Hilditch

data.text: You are very likely right... the idea was just to compare sound quality, level of sound leakage and if they indeed let outside sounds in. My Aftershoks don't do well for phone calls. The other side has always difficulty in understanding me, but I don't know if that's the case just for mine or all. I had other bone conducting headphones before I got the Aeropex, from Aftershoks (I had a Titanium) and other brands. The unknown brand seemed to perform slightly better than the Titanium for phone calls, but sound quality was far inferior. I'm still trying to convince myself to spend these Â£12 though as, coming to think of it, I'll likely not going to replace my Aftershoks for this.
data.author: Paulo Seth

data.text: I use open run
data.author: Patricia Roth

data.text: Before the Shokz. I bought an el-cheapo version from China. It was fake technology. It has little holes that blast the sound to your earholes. It wasn't bone conducting. On a noisy day I couldn't hear a thing. The Shokz works well on noisy roads. I see in your picture that the version also has holes. So maybe this is also a so called bone conduction headphone. But what it really is doing is blasting the sound out of those holes to your ears.
data.author: Rienk Jan Schurer

data.text: Thanks! You may be right, but they don't claim this product to be bone conducting.
data.author: Paulo Seth

data.text: I canâ€™t speak to that brand, but I have the Bose open ear headphones and the sound is amazing, but also nice to hear everything around me. Also people around me canâ€™t hear what Iâ€™m listening tooâ€¦or so Iâ€™m told. I honestly donâ€™t use them much though because I donâ€™t like the interface with the phone, but thatâ€™s a personal preference.
data.author: Megan Rose

data.text: Shokz Open Run are great. You lose some sound quality with bone conduction but the ability to heard the surroundings makes it worth it. I used the previous version "Aftershokz" before the Shokz Open Run during a bike tour across the US on the Transamerica Bicycle Trail. The newer ones have better bass response and a much better (12 hrs) battery life.
data.author: Christopher Lowrance

data.text:
I don't know anything about these.. but want to comment for all those who have not tried a good bone conducting headset recently .. they are much improved. I have AfterShoks and I love mine. For those who do use Bone conducting headsets, I also use 'the CatEar' wind protectors.. they substantially reduce wind noise for me so I can hear at all riding speeds.. they also improve the sound quality for people I am calling. https://www.amazon.com/Cat-Ears-Classic-Cycling-Noise-Reducer/dp/B01H2LSOQ6/ref=asc_df_B01H2LSOQ6/?tag=hyprod-20&linkCode=df0&hvadid=312066961874&hvpos=&hvnetw=g&hvrand=14153604655537949843&hvpone=&hvptwo=&hvqmt=&hvdev=c&hvdvcmdl=&hvlocint=&hvlocphy=9001884&hvtargid=pla-569943316531&psc=1
